For instance, the numbers 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, ..., form a sequence. The order is important; the first number is 2, the second is 4 etc. 

It seems natural to seek a formula that describes a given sequence, and often this can be done. For instance, the sequence above could 

bedescribed by the function  
    a(n) = 2n
,  for the values of  
    n = 1,2,3,4,..,k
. 
 
To find the  
    10^th
  term in the sequence, we would compute  
    a(10)
.  
This leads us to the following, formal definition of a sequence.

Let  {ğš_ğ§}  be a sequence and let  ğ‹  be a real number. Given any  
Îµ> 0 ,  if an  ğ¦  can be found such that  |ğš_ğ§-ğ‹| < Îµ  
for all  ğ§ > ğ¦,
 then we say the limit of  {ğš_ğ§},  as  ğ§  
approaches infinity, is  ğ‹,  denoted 
 
    lim_nâ†’âˆa_n = ğ‹
.

This definition states, informally, that if the limit of a sequence is 
 ğ‹,  then if you go far enough out along the sequence, 

 all subsequent terms will be really close to  ğ‹.
